text: today we're going to show you how to
instantly reduce your anxiety we'll do
this by going over three breathing
methods that you probably don't know
about but are right under your nose
let's jump right into it method number
one cyclic sign we associate sighing
with feeling sad or frustrated but
sighing in a controlled and specific way
can actually be one of the most
effective ways to instantly reduce
stress and anxiety in any situation
cyclic sign involves breathing in
through your nose until your lungs are
comfortably full and then taking another
quick sip of air also through your nose
to expand your lungs to maximum capacity
you then slowly exhale through your
mouth until all the air is gone and
repeat this for five minutes or however
long you need researchers at Stanford
including podcaster and neurobiologist
Dr Andrew huberman whose podcast taught
me about cyclic sign recently conducted
a study that tracked over a hundred
people and asked them to spend five
minutes per day practicing different
breathing exercises for 30 days the
people in the study wore fitness
trackers and regularly had to answer
questions about their mood and anxiety
levels the researchers found that all
the breathing techniques they tested
reduced anxiety but cyclic sign came out
on top doing only one sigh in the way
that I just described was the fastest
way to lower stress levels in the short
term what's more the participants in
this study who did five minutes of
cyclic sign for 30 days also saw the
greatest reduction in Stress and Anxiety
Around the Clock even when they weren't
doing the exercise which translates to
improvements in sleep and lower resting
heart rates at all times of the day
method number two the 478 breathing
technique the 478 method comes from yoga
and has actually been around for
thousands of years it was made popular
recently by Andrew Weil a practitioner
of alternative medicine to practice the
478 method to find a quiet setting and
sit with your back straight keep the tip
of your tongue pressed against the roof
of your mouth just behind your upper
teeth the whole time get rid of all the
air in your lungs then close your mouth
and breathe in through your nose for 4
seconds then you hold your breath while
counting to seven afterwards you breathe
out hard enough to make a whooshing
sound for eight seconds Dr Weil
recommends doing this four times in each
session the idea is to deactivate what's
known as your sympathetic nervous system
and activate what's called your
parasympathetic nervous system when your
sympathetic nervous system is stimulated
you feel anxious your breathing and
heart rate speed up activating your
parasympathetic nervous system does the
opposite and relaxes you just how
effective is this well a 2022 study by
researchers in Thailand followed 43
adults and took various Health measures
before and after they performed the 478
exercise six times for three sets they
found that participants heart rates and
blood pressure significantly improved
immediately after the exercise
suggesting that they experienced a
reduction in Stress and Anxiety and
finally method number three box
breathing box breathing is another deep
breathing technique you can do anywhere
to reduce stress and anxiety it's called
box breathing because you are encouraged
to think of a box while doing it and the
name makes it easy to remember when
you're under pressure the method
involves taking a slow deep breath
through your nose while counting to four
and then holding your breath for four
seconds breathing out slowly through
your mouth for four seconds and then
holding your breath again for another
four seconds before repeating the entire
process do this for a few minutes or
until you've reached the calm State box
breathing is popular amongst people who
work in high stress jobs like soldiers
firefighters and famously the US Navy
Seals because it can take your body out
of fight-or-flight mode and help you
think more clearly in stressful
situations however anyone can use it to
calm down and focus better when feeling
anxious just how effective is box
breathing well a 2017 study found that
people trained in box breathing had
significantly less cortisol in their
spit immediately after performing the
exercise suggesting that it reduce their
stress levels another 2023 study found
that box breathing decreased
participants anxiety levels and boosted
self-reported mood and there you have it
these are three breathing techniques for
reducing anxiety not every method works
for everyone but try them out and let us
know if any worked for you in the
comments down below besides that stay
tuned
